frameDefinitions: A Payer gives up (or potentially gives up) the use of an Asset (generally money) in order to achieve an Intended_event.
These words refer to separating a Whole into Parts, or separating one part from another.
The Borrower takes possession of a Theme with the knowledge that the Borrower will have to give the Theme back to the Lender after a Duration of time.
The words of this frame describe how a Resource_controller spends money or other Resources for a particular purpose .
In this frame, a Resource_controller is judged by a Judge (who is usually implicit)  according to how freely they allow the Recipient access to their Resource.
Temporary or permanent Styles and Configurations of Hair, as well as its inherent Nature.
frameExamples: It 'll <t>cost</t> Sandra's parents fifty grand a year for her to attend that school.
I <t>divided</t> the class into groups in alphabetical order .
I am <t>borrowing</t> the book about modal particles from the professor.
On either side her head gleamed coiled <t>braids</t> of dark-gold hair , almost pale copper in the subdued light of the room .
listRoleDefinitions: The role <fen>Goods</fen> is the item(s) whose price is being assessed.  <fen>Goods</fen> is usually an External Argument:
The person whose <fen>Asset</fen> is given up in order to achieve an <fen>Intended_event</fen>.  This role is often expressed as INI.
The price of or payment made for the Goods.
The event that the <fen>Payer</fen> brings about by deploying the <fen>Asset</fen>.
The time when a transaction takes place.
The <fen>Whole</fen> is a single entity or an aggregate of entities which is separated into <fen>Parts</fen>.  It is usually the NP Object of a target verb.
This refers collectively to the Parts resulting from separation of a Whole:
Part-1 is the first of two Parts mentioned. This is most often the Object of a verb.
<fen>Part_2</fen> is the second of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. This is usually a PP Complement. First,
With causative uses of these verbs, an Agent separates or divides something.  The Agent is usually expressed as the External Argument:
The <fen>Cause</fen> is the non-agent that brings about the separation.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the separation occurs.
Where the separation occurs.
The person who receives the <fen>Theme</fen> from the <fen>Lender</fen> for a <fen>Duration</fen>.
The person or institution who gives the <fen>Theme</fen> to the <fen>Borrower</fen> for a <fen>Duration</fen>.
The object that the <fen>Borrower</fen> receives from the <fen>Lender</fen> for a <fen>Duration</fen>.
When the borrowing even occurs.
The location in which the <fen>Borrower</fen> gets the <fen>Theme</fen> from the <fen>Lender</fen>.

The <fen>Resource_controller</fen> is the individual whose frugality or generosity is being described. Person typically occurs as the External Argument or, in some cases when <fen>Behavior</fen> is also expressed, in an <ment>of</ment>-PP:
Some specific <fen>Behavior</fen> may be described as frugal or extravagant, rather than attributing the characteristic directly to the <fen>Resource_controller</fen>.
This role is the resource which the <fen>Resource_controller</fen> expends.
The Resource_Controller is the individual who controls access to the Resource.
The Resource_controller controls the Recipient's access to the Resource.
The <fen>Recipient</fen> is the individual or individuals who receive or should receive the <fen>Resource</fen> from the <fen>Resource_controller</fen>.
The Behavior is an action of the Resource_controller which is judged to be generous or stingy.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part which indicates the character of the <fen>Resource_controller</fen>.
This role is the hair itself
This role is the Possessor of the body part.
Temporary Configurations of hair (eg braid, bun, ponytail).   Something done to the hair merely by movement.
A property of the hair (eg curly, fine, brown).  This acts much like 'Descriptor' in the Observable_bodyparts Frame.  Colors, styles, natural properties are described by this frame element.
listRoleExamples: <fex>These paintings</fex> are very pricey.
A holiday in Europe is very expensive <fex>for me</fex>.
The painting was cheap <fex>at $600</fex>.
<fex>Attending summer school</fex> is expensive.
No, they've got a special on; it's really cheap there <fex>on Tuesdays</fex>
The directors split <fex>the company</fex> in two.
The directors split the company <fex>in two</fex>.
First, separate <fex>the yolks</fex> from the whites.
separate the yolks <fex>from the whites</fex>.
<fex>The researcher</fex> divided subjects into groups.
I divided the prize money among the winners <fex>that night</fex>.
You should separate the yolks from the whites <fex>over the sink</fex>.
<fex>Tracy</fex> borrowed that book from Leonard last week.
Tracy borrowed that book <fex>from Leonard</fex> last week.
I am borrowing his car <fex>at the airport</fex>.
<fex>Jo</fex> is very frugal.
It's thrifty of Jo <fex>to re-use teabags</fex>.
Pat is wasteful <fex>with her time</fex>.
<fex>Stampy</fex> was stingy with his peanuts.
Surprising, Dad was stingy <fex>with his inheritance</fex>.
Mr. Burns is extremely miserly <fex>towards his employees</fex>.
It was generous of Jim <fex>to have us over for dinner</fex>.
Her <fex><t>tresses</t></fex> were golden.
<fex>Michael's</fex> hair is long.
I pulled Michael's  <fex>ponytail</fex>.
